channel.title: DirectX binding for Java
channel.description: Afaik there is no binding for Java (only did some brief researching) so I was wondering what I would have to look into to make my own.

item.title: DirectX binding for Java
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:21, topic:442467”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=545159.msg3998458#msg3998458 date=1337618170]
I’m really confused right now. Almost anything you’d want to do in DirectX (minus maybe some of the most recent features) are available in OpenGL, too. You would have no problems achieving everything you want in OpenGL, especially since most of the things in your list have nothing to do with the underlying graphics pipeline, anyway.
[/quote]
This is what I was unsure of. I wasn’t sure if OpenGL offered everything I wanted, however I knew that DirectX would with no doubt. That’s why I wanted to know if there was a binding for DirectX just in case/to mess around with.[/quote]

There are no doubt directx bindings for Java. And, if those don’t suit your needs, you can always write your own. JNI is easy enough to work with.

Read full topic

item.title: DirectX binding for Java
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Taharok:

I’m really confused right now. Almost anything you’d want to do in DirectX (minus maybe some of the most recent features) are available in OpenGL, too. You would have no problems achieving everything you want in OpenGL, especially since most of the things in your list have nothing to do with the underlying graphics pipeline, anyway.

This is what I was unsure of. I wasn’t sure if OpenGL offered everything I wanted, however I knew that DirectX would with no doubt. That’s why I wanted to know if there was a binding for DirectX just in case/to mess around with.

Read full topic

item.title: DirectX binding for Java
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I’m really confused right now. Almost anything you’d want to do in DirectX (minus maybe some of the most recent features) are available in OpenGL, too. You would have no problems achieving everything you want in OpenGL, especially since most of the things in your list have nothing to do with the underlying graphics pipeline, anyway.

As far as that video goes, there’s so much to understand about that. You have no idea what the underlying implementations were, what graphics cards, drivers, and driver versions were being used, what versions of DirectX versus OpenGL were being used, whether the shaders were actually identical or slightly different, and so on. It’s also worth noting that on many NVidia implementations of OpenGL, they actually just recompile the GLSL shaders to CG and bind the OpenGL function calls to a DirectX wrapper. You’d be essentially seeing almost the exact same thing programmed using both libraries (unless, again, you are using selective DirectX features).

Read full topic

item.title: DirectX binding for Java
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote="_s, post:17, topic:442467"][quote author=The Wanderer link=topic=545159.msg3996570#msg3996570 date=1337365716]
Well i’m not sure if opengl has all that I want as I want the ability to redo topology on meshes, add non-uniform rational b spline modeling, realistic rendering and maybe catmull-Clark subdivision to name a few. I may also implement a “conveter” from geometry to voxels and implement a sparse voxel octree is you wanted to do quick real time rendering with voxels for the fun of it. I know directx would have support for all of my needs as iirc 3ds requires you to have directx and the new tesselation in dx11looks nifty.
[/quote]you fuzzed up the line between modelling and renderer a bit. i suggest you look at what blender (http://www.blender.org/) is capable of (nurbs and catmull-clark subdivision are implemented in it) also opengl 4.0+ has tessellation shaders.[/quote] well normally you take a modeling software and install/buy a rendering plugin (such as vray for 3ds max which costs around 100$ iirc) for realism quality so I was planning on developing both as it would be really fun imo. another factor I would like to consider is rendering times as sometimes realistic renders can take upwards of 30 hours so if the majority of gpus are made to take advantage of directxs features before opengl I would definitely want to use directx.

Edit- also blender is more known for its wonderful animation and horrible ui up until the new beta (not really new anymore lol). Last time I checked all of the plugins for realistic rendering were decent, but wasn’t on par with vray. That may be because blender is free and 3ds max costs 3000$ too. Not sure or maybe my memory fails me.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Well i’m not sure if opengl has all that I want as I want the ability to redo topology on meshes, add non-uniform rational b spline modeling, realistic rendering and maybe catmull-Clark subdivision to name a few. I may also implement a “conveter” from geometry to voxels and implement a sparse voxel octree is you wanted to do quick real time rendering with voxels for the fun of it. I know directx would have support for all of my needs as iirc 3ds requires you to have directx and the new tesselation in dx11looks nifty.

item.title: DirectX binding for Java
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“The Wanderer, post:10, topic:442467”][quote author=(Anthony) link=topic=545159.msg3996256#msg3996256 date=1337302465]
PLZ DON’T DO IT WE’RE ALL GOING TO DIE.
[/quote]lol you’re funny

why directx

Particles

is that a joke

yes. Because hardware makers generally update quicker to d3d than opengl. And I also wanted to mess around with both to see which I liked more as they both function differently. only thing I dont like is that directx doesnt supoort more OS than windows without stuff like wine and such.

DirectX blows

Yeah? why do you say so? so far all I’ve read is that they are basically the same thing besides opengl is multi-os and directx was developed by microsoft. and the fact that Direct3D expects the application to manage hardware resources whereas OpenGL makes the implementation do it.[/quote]and unless you’re really needing the resource control offered by directx it’s just extra shit that’ll get in your way

Read full topic

item.title: DirectX binding for Java
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

The Wanderer:

there’s always wine and such for other os though.

Wine is still on d3d9, so i hope you’re not doing it for the sole reason of it being updated quicker… Manufacturers are pretty good at keeping up with the releases anyways

And BTW they still have a long ways to go: http://www.winehq.org/site/status/directx

Read full topic
